loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay for crop maintenance.

loans.name: Santos Claudia

texts.es: Doña Santos, tiene 48 años de edad, es madre soltera, vive solo con sus dos hijas en el municipio de Tocoa, Colon. Actualmente tiene su propio negocio de una pulpería donde vende productos de la canasta básica, como ser arroz, azúcar, harina, pollo, carne, refrescos etc., este negocio lo tiene hace 1 año con 3 meses en su casa. Anteriormente se dedicaba a la sastrería y para obtener más ingresos decidió por la pulpería. El préstamo que solicita es por 15,000 lempiras, el cual lo invertirá en la compra de productos alimenticios como arroz, azúcar, frijoles, maíz, lácteos, carnes, jugos, harina, refrescos, y embutidos para mantener surtido el negocio. Su plan es tener su negocio grande.
texts.en:
Santos, 48, is a single mother who lives with her two daughters in the municipality of Tocoa, Colon.  She currently runs a grocery store where she sells essential products such as rice, sugar, flour, chicken, meat, soft drinks, etc.  She has been in business for a year and three months and the store is located in her home.

She used to work as a seamstress but decided to open the grocery store to earn more income.  The loan she is requesting in the amount of 15,000 HNL is to buy food products such as rice, sugar, beans, corn, dairy products, meats, juices, flour, soft drinks and sausages to stock her business.  Her plan is to expand her store.

loans.use: To buy food products such as rice, sugar, beans, corn, dairy products, meat, juices, flour, soft drinks and sausages.

loans.name: Eli Jonatan

texts.es:
Eli, tiene un cibercafé, que beneficia  a la niñez y estudiantes de escasos recursos, ya que ofrece  sus servicios a precios a accesibles, además también realiza la reparación de computadoras, filmaciones  y fotografías de eventos especiales, en sus inicios su negocio solo tenía tres computadoras ha ido mejorando su equipo y actualmente ya cuenta con un número mayor de computadoras.
Le servirá para comprar repuestos para computadoras y material necesario para las filmaciones, de esta manera se mantendrá trabajando por un largo tiempo y cumpliendo con sus contratos, espera tener más ganancias y un mejor desarrollo social sostenible.
Sus anhelos son incrementar sus ventas, cancelar sus deudas y que sus hijos desarrollen la habilidad de administrar el negocio.
texts.en:
Eli has a cybercafe that benefits youth and students with little income since the services are offered at low prices.  He also repairs computers, and does photography and videos for special events.  He started out with only three computers but now has more units, having added better equipment over time.

The loan he is requesting is to buy spare parts for the computers and the material he needs for the video recording activity.  This will help him stay in business longer so he can fill orders.  He hopes to earn more and develop a socially sustainable business.

His goals are to increase sales, pay off debts and see that his children develop management skills for the business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for computers and video equipment for his work.

loans.name: Edwin Reyes

texts.es:
Edwin, está casado, vive con su esposa y un hijo de 6 años de edad; se dedica a cultivar granos básicos y administra una tienda de productos de la canasta básica, la cual está instalada en su domicilio, el negocio lo heredo de su familia y se lo enseño su padre.
Invertirá en la compra de aceite, azúcar, arroz, sal, pan, huevos, etc., le será de utilidad para tener una mejor variedad de productos y abastecer a sus clientes con lo que necesiten, espera que sus ventas aumenten y  sus ganancias mejoren.
La aspiración de Edwin es tener una tienda más grande y cumplir con sus compromisos.
texts.en:
Edwin is married and lives with his wife and six-year-old son.  He cultivates basic grains and runs a grocery store out of his home.  He inherited the store from his family and was taught to run it by his father.

The loan he is requesting is to buy oil, sugar, rice, salt, bread, eggs, etc. to add more products to supply to customers.  He hopes to increase sales and earn more profit.  Edwin aspires to having a larger store and fulfilling his commitments.

loans.use: To buy oil, sugar, rice, salt, bread, eggs, etc. to add variety at his store.

loans.name: Palabra De Mujer Group

texts.es: Sonia de 38 años de edad es separada con 02 hijos independientes. Este es el grupo “Palabra De Mujer” La cual  está constituida por 07 socios emprendedores y entusiastas. Sonia se desempeña como cobradora de pasajes en su medio de transportes urbano. Con el fruto de su esfuerzo ha podido darles una mejor educación a sus menores hijos. Solicitó el crédito para el mantenimiento de su vehículo. Su mayor anhelo es contar con una tienda de abarrotes. El grupo “Palabra de Mujer” agradece a todas las personas que facilitaron este crédito. Sonia es la primera del lado izquierdo y viste polo amarillo.
texts.en: This is the "Palabra de Mujer" group, which has seven enterprising and enthusiastic members. Sonia is one of them. She is 38 years old and separated. She has two children who are now independent. Sonia works as a bus conductor on the local buses. With the money that she earns from this work, she was able to give her youngest children an education. Sonia is applying for this loan in order to maintain her vehicle. Sonia's biggest wish is to own a grocery store. The "Palabra de Mujer" group thanks all those who are making this loan possible. In the photo, Sonia is the first on the left, wearing a yellow t-shirt.

loans.use: to maintain her vehicle, which is also her main work tool.

loans.name: Kevin Daniel

texts.es:
Kevin es un joven emprendedor, tiene 22 años de edad, es soltero y vive en Ucayali junto a su familia.
Es una persona con muchas ganas de salir adelante. Tiene varios hermanos y como los recursos económicos eran muy escasos en su hogar tuvo que salir a trabajar, por lo que ahora es una persona independiente que trabaja para pagarse sus estudios y a la vez apoya a su familia. Su gran esfuerzo se ve reflejado hoy en su trabajo y la clase de persona en la que se ha convertido, todo un ejemplo a seguir para sus hermanos.
Kevin está agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva por el apoyo que le han brindado ya que con ello él podrá comprar un juego de mueble para su casa, de esta manera estará mejorando su calidad de vida y con esto seguirá trabajando mucho para más adelante poder cumplir una de sus más grandes metas: "Ser un gran empresario".
texts.en:
Kevin is an enterprising young man. He is 22 years old, single and lives in Ucayali with his family.

Kevin has a great desire to get ahead in life. He has a number of siblings and, given that the family was very poor, Kevin had to go out to work. As a result, Kevin is now independent. He works to pay for his studies and, at the same time, support his family. Kevin's great efforts can be seen in his work and in the person that he has become; Kevin is a role-model for his siblings.

Kevin is grateful to Kiva lenders for their support. With it, he will be able to buy furniture for his house. By doing this, he will be able to improve his quality of life. Kevin will then continue to work a lot in order, in the future, to achieve one of his biggest dreams: of being a businessman.

loans.use: to buy furniture for his house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilisers to look after crops.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en: Jamila lives in Hoima, Uganda. She is 28 years old. She is single with the responsibility of taking care of two children who are 10 and 2 years old. She runs a bar. She is a hard-working woman who desires to expand her business. However, competition affects her business. She is acquiring a loan to buy more soft drinks and beers to sell.

loans.use: buy more soft drinks and beers for sell.

loans.name: Marta Alicia

texts.es:
Marta, manifiesta que la ayuda brindada por Kiva le ha sido de mucho beneficio para tener un mejor desarrollo tanto en su negocio como en su vida familiar, tiene nuevos clientes, ha cancelado sus deudas e incrementado sus ingresos.
Por el aumento de la demanda de sus clientes necesita surtir su inventario con más mercadería, por lo que requiere más capital para comprar golosinas, bebidas, granos básicos, huevos entre otros productos necesarios para fortalecer su negocio y tener los buenos resultados del crédito anterior.
texts.en:
Marta says that the help provided by Kiva was of great use to her. She was able to grow, both in her work and with her family. She has new customers, has paid her debts, and increased her income. 

With an increase in customer demand, Marta needs to stock up her business with more merchandise. As a result she needs more capital in order to buy sweets, drinks, basic grains, eggs and other necessary products to strengthen her business and enjoy the same good results as with her previous loan.

loans.use: to buy sweets, drinks, basic grains, eggs and other necessary products to strengthen her business.

loans.name: Angela Del Carmen

texts.es:
Ángela, requiere de un nuevo financiamiento para mejorar la mercadería que oferta en su tienda, comprara bebidas, golosinas, aceite, granos básicos, azúcar, sal, galletas y otros productos que le ayuden a tener un mejor inventario en su negocio.
Con el préstamo anterior mejoro el negocio, mantiene a sus clientes satisfechos y su familia tiene un mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Ángela needs a new loan in order to increase the merchandise on sale in her shop. She will use this loan to buy drinks, sweets, oil, basic grains, sugar, salt, biscuits and other products that will help to have better stock in her business.

Ángela used her previous loan to improve her business, keep her customers satisfied, and give her family a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy drinks, sweets, oil, basic grains, sugar, salt, biscuits and other products that will help to have better stock in her business.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline, age 28, is a divorced, hardworking lady living in Hoima, Uganda. She has a salon and sells cosmetics, which is supplemented by rental income. As a single mother, Jackline started her business to have a better future and to take care of her children, who are between 5 and 8 years old. Competition, coupled with inadequate capital, hinder her business. She desires to expand her business. She is acquiring a loan to buy cosmetics for resale and to use in her salon.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics for resale and to use in her salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothes and renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is a hard-working woman. Scovia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which deals in phone repair. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 800,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy new phones and housings, and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her younger siblings. Scovia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business and become a good supplier. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy new phones and housings

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en: Rustam is a 31-year-old married man. He is asking for a loan of 1,100 AZN so that he can obtain a water pump to irrigate and expand his vegetable crops. Vegetable gardening is a big business for many rural farmers in his region. Rustam grows vegetables on his small farm to sell at one of the roadside markets. His father helps him in this business. Last season he grew cabbages, tomatoes, cucumbers, and watermelons. His monthly income is 400 AZN from this business. Rustam needs your financial support. He is thankful to Kiva and the Aqroinvest Credit Union for a loan.

loans.use: to buy a water pump to irrigate his vegetable crops

loans.name: Baby Bay Group

texts.en: Gemma is the featured borrower of Baby Bay Group. She joined with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, because they have always been friends, ever since they left their hometown in the Philippines to work in Lebanon for better incomes to support their loved ones. Gemma is a 40-year-old widowed mother of four who works as a housekeeper to provide her family with a better living. Life in the Philippines is very expensive and job opportunities are limited. Gemma is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, to pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees. Gemma is the lady standing at the left side of the picture with the brown top. As for the other group members, Glenly is the lady at the far right side of the picture with the purple top, Liberty is the second lady from the left with the pink top, Flora is the second from the right with the grey top, while Jeniffer is the lady at the top center of the picture with her face appearing.

loans.use: To pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees

loans.name: Markus

texts.en: Markus is a Babban Gona farmer from Nasarawa. Markus expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Markus to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Markus can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Markus, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Markus will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Markus will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Sule

texts.en: Sule remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Sule like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Sule,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. Sule expressed that “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Sule is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a hard-working woman. Christine is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has one child. For the past year, Christine has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells food. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more plates, cups, chairs, and other items for the restaurant, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her family. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a motorbike for her business. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more plates, cups, chairs, and other items for the restaurant

loans.name: Abduljalal

texts.en: Abduljalal is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abduljalal joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Aliyu, Abubakar, and  Idris. Abduljalal is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Abduljalal will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Abduljalal can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Abduljalal is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Las Flores Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LAS FLORES”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de San Sebastián, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Isabel ella es soltera y tiene 49 años y tiene 1 hijo; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite, la socia trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 9 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar leche, azúcar, aceite y arroz.
 La socia que esta pegada a la foto grupal se le tomo despues la foto porque pidio permiso por motivos de trabajo.

La socia que esta tapado con un circulo su rostro ya no pertenece al banco comunal Las Flores.

 Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de tortas, negocio de cabinas de venta de ropa, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de restaurant.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the communal bank "LAS FLORES",  in the district of San Sebastian, province of Cusco and department of Cusco.

The member is Isabel. She is unmarried and 49 years old. She has 1 son. She has a grocery store business. She sells basic necessities such as rice, sugar, milk and oil. The member works from 6:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m.  Isabel has already had this business for 9 years and is doing very well. Her dream  is to expand the  grocery store business. 

She is asking for the loan in order to buy milk, sugar, oil and rice.

The member attached to the group photograph had her photo taken later; she requested permission for work reasons.

The member whose face is hidden by a circle no longer belongs to the communal bank "LAS FLORES".

The other members are engaged in the businesses of selling cakes, selling clothing from stalls, grocery stores and restaurants.

Isabel thanks all those who form part of this dream, through this medium, and is committed to complying with the payment of her dues in the time agreed.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, oil and rice.

loans.name: Alh. Hudu

texts.en: Alh. Hudu remembers not being able to feed his family  as a result of a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Alh. Hudu, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Hudu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season because he will finally be able to afford improved seed varieties and the requisite quantity of fertilizer. “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Alh. Hudu.  With this loan, Alh. Hudu is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: El Paraiso Group

texts.es: Esta es la Alcancía “El Paraíso” La cual  está constituida por 06 socios solidarios y entusiastas. Marisela de 52 años de edad es separada con 01 hijo independiente. Ella se dedica  a la venta de calzados. Y a su vez como actividad secundaria se desempeña como docente.  Actualmente en su negocio ha podido implementar nuevos modelos de zapatos, lo que le permite ser más competitiva. Solicitó el crédito para la compra zapatillas, calzados de vestir y botines. La Alcancía “El Paraíso” agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por facilitarles este crédito. Marisela es la segunda del lado  izquierdo y viste polo azul.
texts.en:
This is the communal bank “El Paraíso”. It is comprised of six enthusiastic members who help each other. Marisela, 52, is divorced and has a son who is independent. She sells shoes and works as a teacher.

She has been able to offer a wider variety of shoes lately, which has made her business more competitive. She requested this loan to buy sneakers, casual shoes and ankle boots. This group wants to thank Kiva lenders for helping them with this loan. Marisela is standing second, from left to right. She is wearing a blue shirt.

loans.use: to buy sneakers, casual shoes and ankle boots.

loans.name: Micah

texts.en: Micah is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Micah joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Yushau,Biliya, and Habu. Micah is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Micah will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Micah can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Micah is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Elisha

texts.en: Elisha is a 40-year-old farmer from Dogon Fako.  As a Babban Gona member, Elisha, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Elisha can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Elisha is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Elisha is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children. Elisha’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: "lamp Fall" 3" Beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit « Lamp Fall 3 » « Beug Manal Sa Bop » est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes commerçantes et transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus.
Madame Penda, la responsable, tient un étale dans le marché, elle vend du poisson frais depuis près de 10 ans déjà. Le financement va donc lui permettre d’augmenter la quantité de produits à acheter, diversifier la marchandise et améliorer les conditions alimentaires de sa famille. 
Elle veut acquérir une pirogue pour maximiser son profit.
texts.en:
The "Lamp Fall 3" "Beug Manal Sa Bop" loan group is a sub-group of a network of trading women and women who make products from fish. It is made up of five women who have been working for several years and who have got together so that they can get financial aid in order to enable them to boost their income-generating activities.

Penda, who is in charge of the group, has a stall in the market where she has been selling fresh fish for almost ten years now. The loan will enable her to increase the amount of products she can buy, to diversify her merchandise and improve her family's nutrition. She would like to acquire a pirogue in order to maximise her profit.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish for resale.

loans.name: Andonassoumana 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe ANDONASSOUMANA 3 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans, ont en moyenne 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à TOLA un village dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de riz avec madame OUMOU débout à la première position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme  ANDONASSOUMANA 3. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 74 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Andonassoumana 3 group are married women, who average 29 years old and have an average of three children each; the majority of them live in traditional families in Tola, a village in the Sikasso circle, Mali's third administrative region. They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, so that they can carry out their farming activities successfully during the winter season. They are on their fifth seasonal loan with Soro Yiriwaso, and their previous loans have been repaid in full.

Within this group, Oumou, who is standing on the far right of the photo, grows rice. With her loan, she is planning to buy two 50-kilo sacks of fertilizer and a container of weedkiller, as well as to pay for labor to maintain 0,5 hectares of land. Once harvested, the produce is sold in the village, in Sikasso to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. 

She expects to make an average profit of 74,000FCFA per season. This profit will enable her to repay her loan and the interest on it, and also help out her husband with the family's daily outgoings.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and weedkillers, as well as to pay for labor.

With access to high quality inputs, Sallau can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. texts.en: Garba remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Garba, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Garba is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed  Garba. With this loan, Garba is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase his capital and buy 40 portable telephones and 1,000 kilos of palm nuts for resale, so that he can earn more.

loans.name: Muco Group

texts.fr:
Vincent  fait partie du groupe  Muco et  habite à  Bujumbura. Il a 41 ans et est marié à Thérèse, une commerçante. Ensemble ils ont 7 enfants âgés de 4 à 19 ans. 

Il  fait le commerce de  boutique (haricot, savon,…) depuis  12 ans. 

Il est à son deuxième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  de 50 kilos de riz et 70 kilos de haricot à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait voir se enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Vincent belongs to the Muco group and lives in Bujumbura. He is 41 years old and married to Thérèse, a trader. They have seven children together, whose ages range from four to 19 years old.

He has been selling shop products (beans, soap..) for the past 12 years and is on his second loan from Turame. With the Kiva loan he is granted, he is going to increase his capital and buy 50 kilos of rice and 70 kilos of beans, which he will resell to earn more money.

In the coming years he would like to see his children through school.

loans.use: to increase his capital and buy 50 kilos of rice and 70 kilos of beans for resale, so that he can earn more.

loans.name: Marisela De La Cruz

texts.es:
Marisela  de 38 anos de edad, madre soltera con tres hijos menores de edad, es originaria de Leon, lugar que está ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Esta joven mujer es muy trabajadora,  responsable, con mucha responsabilidad con sus tres hijos, los cuales todos están estudiando. La situación económica de ella es bien difícil porque tiene que luchar duro diariamente para poder mantener surtida su pulpería  el cual es su medio de vida y la de sus hijos.
Gracias  a sus ganas de salir adelante tiene por actividad económica una pulpería, es una pequeña tienda que vende productos comestibles en cantidades pequeñas como: arroz, frijoles, azúcar, leche, pan, huevos, detergente, jugos, galletas, aceite. Ella dedica a su negocio unas doce horas diarias ofreciendo sus productos. y de dicha forma brindar buen servicio a sus clientes y en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio.  Marisela agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Marisela is 38 years old. She is a single mother of three minor children. She is from Leon, located in the western part of the city. This young woman is very hardworking, and very responsible with her three children, who are in school. Her financial situation is very difficult because she has to fight every day to be able to keep her store stocked. It the way she supports her self and her children.  

Thanks to her drive to get ahead, she has a store for her economic activity. It is a small store that sells edible products in small quantities, such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, detergent, juices, cookies, and oil. She works at her business twelve hours a day, offering her products. This is how she offers her customers a good service so that in a not so distant future she can obtain better income. The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and stocking her business. Marisela is grateful to the Kiva investors for the help they give to people of low income and poor countries such as Nicaragua so they can have dignified work.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and stock her business by buying and selling edible products such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, detergent, soap, juices, and cookies.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a married mother of one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.
	
For the past three years, she has operated a clothes and shoes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 30,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes and shoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a  and member of Babban Gona. Mary joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her  children: Faith, and Precious,. Mary is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Mary will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Mary can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Mary is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that her long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Shuaibu

texts.en: Shuaibu is a Babban Gona farmer from Dogon Fako. Shuaibu is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Shuaibu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Shuaibu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Shuaibu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Shuaibu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Shuaibu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ado

texts.en: Ado is a Babban Gona farmer from Dogon fako. Ado is driven by one goal: to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” It is this ambition that led Ado to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ado can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Ado is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Ado is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home.  Ultimately, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Ado will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Khelcom 5"beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Khelcom 5 est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. La présidente s’appelle Khady, elle s’active dans la transformation de poisson et exerce le métier depuis plusieurs années. Le crédit lui permettra d’acheter du poisson frais pour le transformer. 
Khady est mariée et mère de famille. Elle participe à la dépense quotidienne de la famille grâce aux bénéfices réalisés.
Elle désire se lancer aussi dans l’agriculture pour diversifier ses sources de revenus et améliorer les conditions alimentaires de la famille.
texts.en: The Khelcom 5 Group is a subgroup of a network of female processors of fish products. The group consists of five women who have been active for several years. They gathered to benefit from financial assistance that enables them to strengthen their income-generating activities. Khady is the president. She has been in the business of processing fish for several years. The loan will enable her to buy fresh fish for processing. She is married and mother of a family. Thanks to the profits she earns, she helps take care of her family's daily expenses.  She also wants to start farming to diversify her income sources and improve the food conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish.

loans.name: Sehira

texts.en:
Sehira is 51 year old, married, and has two children. She is a housewife and farmer. 

To support the family, she and her husband have been growing fruit and vegetables for 25 years. Raising of seasonal fruits is very common in Azerbaijan because people have a high demand for fresh fruits. They use fruits to make juice, jam, fruit pies and fruit cocktails. People visit her grocery because fruits there are always fresh and tasty.
 
Her income from this business is 200 AZN. She is applying for a loan 600 AZN to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She believes this loan will have a positive impact on the expansion of her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Nagiwa's Group

texts.en:
Nagiwa's group is composed of five hardworking women. Nagiwa is 18 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has one child. For the past 1 1/2 years, Nagiwa has been working hard to manage her small shoe business, which sells all types of shoes. 

To help expand her business, Nagiwa has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shoes for sale, and it will help Nagiwa to generate greater profits and rent a bigger shop. Nagiwa hopes that in the future she will be able to build her own house. 

Nagiwa is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more shoes for sale.

loans.name: Sop Mame Diarra 9"beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Sop Mame Diarra 9 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes commerçantes et transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. Madame Anta Salla est la présidente ; elle est mariée et mère de famille. Son activité consiste à vendre des tissus, des chaussures et de l’habillement (pantalons, ensembles…) Cela fait plus de 10 ans qu’elle exerce ce métier. Grâce au financement, Anta Salla va augmenter son fond de roulement pour pouvoir acquérir d’autres variétés de tissus, chaussures et revendre. Elle paie les factures d’électricité et d’eau, c’est sa participation à la gestion des charges du foyer. 
Si elle voit son capital augmenter, elle pense à ouvrir une boutique de vente de cosmétiques, de tissus et de chaussures.
texts.en: The Sop Mame Diarra 9 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » Group is a subgroup of a network of female business owners and processors of fish products. The group consists of five women who have been active for several years. They gathered to benefit from financial assistance that enables them to strengthen their income-generating activities. Ms. Anta Salla is the president. She is married and mother of a family. She has been selling fabric, shoes, and clothing (pants, outfits, etc) for over 10 years. This loan will enable her to increase her working capital and buy different kinds of fabric and shoes for resale. She contributes to the household expenses by paying the electricity and water bills. If she sees her capital increasing, she will think about opening a store for selling cosmetics, fabric, and shoes.

loans.use: to buy fabric and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Sop Mame Babacar 5" Beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Sop Mame Babacar 5 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. Ngoné est la responsable du groupe, elle s’active dans la transformation de poissons frais en poissons séchés et fumés destinés à la commercialisation. Elle a une expérience de plus de 10 ans et reste active de 6h du matin à 17h heures. Ngoné pratique ces 2 activités car elle a 2 sites : à »  Khelcom » ou se fait la transformation du poisson fumé et au » Tann », celui du poisson séché.
Avec les revenus de son activité, elle appuie son mari dans la gestion de la maison.
Ngoné veut devenir une grande exportatrice de ses produits vers d’autres régions.
texts.en: The Sop Mame Babacar 5 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » Group is a subgroup of a network of female processors of fish products. The group consists of five women who have been active for several years. They gathered to benefit from financial assistance that enables them to strengthen their income-generating activities. Ngone is the group manager. She turns fresh fish into dried and smoked fish for resale.  She has over 10 years of experience and works from 6 am to 5 pm. Ngone conducts two businesses because she has two locations: in Khelcom, she makes smoked fish and in Tann, she makes dried fish.  With the income from her business, she helps her husband with managing the household. Ngone wants to become a large exporter of her products to other regions.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish.

loans.name: Herenia

texts.en:
Herenia is 63 years old and a widowed mother. 

She is a diligent mother who is engaged in a livestock business. She has a fishpond and a piggery business. 

To generate daily income, Herenia is also engaged in processing and selling vinegar and dish sauce. She still has the eagerness to work and succeed. Herenia wants to borrow additional capital of PHP 50,000 to buy components used in processing vinegar and dish sauce. Herenia hopes to grow the business and leave it for her children if ever she will leave them.

loans.use: to buy components used in processing vinegar and dish sauce.

loans.name: Flora Alicia

texts.es:
Flora, mantiene su venta de comida y tortillas funcionado,  necesita capital para abastecer de materia prima su negocio comprara maíz, leña, carnes, embutidos, arroz, pastas, verduras, lácteos, etc., para la elaboración de la venta de comida y las tortillas, así se mantendrá trabajando.
El préstamo anterior le permitió mejorar el negocio, estabilizarse económicamente, cambiar la alimentación, vestuario y salud de su familia. Con las ganancias ha incluido la venta de comida a precios bajos.
texts.en:
Flora is still running her business selling food and tortillas. She needs capital to stock up on raw materials for her business. She will buy corn, firewood, meat, deli meats, rice, vegetables, dairy products, etc., to make and sell the food and the tortilla. This way, she will keep working. 

The previous loan allowed her to improve the business, get financially established, and change the food and clothing for her family. The earnings have allowed her to sell her food at low prices.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, meats, deli meats, rice, pasta, vegetables, dairy products, etc., to make and sell tortillas.

loans.name: Praxides

texts.es:
La socia Praxides se dedica al negocio de venta de carne, la socia vende carne en el mercado desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene 7 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de carne. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar carne.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Praxides wirks at the business of selling meat. She sells meat in the market from 8:00 a.m until 6:00 p.m. She has had this business for 7 years and it is going well for her. Her dream is to expand her meat selling business. She is asking for the loan to buy meat. 

She is happy with the loan and committed to making her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy meat.

loans.name: Ezikiel

texts.en: Ezikiel is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ezikiel joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Mashen,Florene, and Comfidence. Ezikiel is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ezikiel will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ezikiel can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Ezikiel is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an air conditioner and a generator and to renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a hardworking woman. Florence is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has two children with none of them currently in school. 

For the past one month, Florence has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells snacks and cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy essential commodities for the restaurant, and it will help Florence to generate greater profits and purchase a television and solar lamp. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger retail shop. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy essential commodities for the restaurant.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman. Amina owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Amina operates a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other vegetable sellers in her business.
 
With the KES 25,000, she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits, and green vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits, and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Inusa

texts.en: Inusa is a 25 year old farmer from Babbar Saura.  As a Babban Gona member, Inusa is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Inusa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Inusa  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season. When asked, Inusa said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en: Mathew is a 28-year-old farmer from Dogon Fako.  As a Babban Gona member, Mathew is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Mathew can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Mathew is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Mathew is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children. Mathew’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Garba

texts.en: Garba is a 45 year old farmer from Babbar Saura.  As a Babban Gona member, Garba is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Garba can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Garba,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season. When asked , Garba said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, he is well  on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Rossmark

texts.en: Rossmark owns and operates an agriculture business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rossmark has been engaged in his business for six years and earns well from these activities. His farm is still doing well and yet, he needs financial assistance to improve it. Recently, he took a new loan to buy fertilizer. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his farm to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Abdullahi

texts.en: Abdullahi is a Babban Gona farmer from Babbar Saura. Abdullahi is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is this ambition that led Abdullahi to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Abdullahi can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Abdullahi is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Abdullahi is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home.  Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Abdullahi will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en:
Tabu is a married woman. She has two children and one of them attends school. Tabu owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family and fees for her child.

Tabu operates a motorcycle transport business from door to door where passersby and town dwellers are her potential customers. She faces a challenge of seasonality, especially during rainy season when it becomes difficult to operate the business. 

With the KES 50,000 she wants to add to her savings and purchase a new motorcycle. Tabu joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to add to her savings and purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a married mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household consumables.

For over two years, she has operated an open air food-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat.

loans.name: "lamp Fall" Port 10"beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit « Lamp Fall « Port 10 « Beug Manal Sa Bop » est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes commerçantes et transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. Seyni Gadio est la présidente    du groupe. Elle s’active dans le commerce depuis plus de 5 ans. Elle a démarré son activité de vente de poisson avec un capital de 100 000F et actuellement cette dernière tourne autour de 500 000f. Ce crédit lui permet d’augmenter ses fonds afin d’acheter du poisson de qualité et pouvoir le revendre dans les hôtels. Seyni Gadio est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont elle s’occupe en participant à leur éducation en leur payant des cours de renforcement.
Elle rêve de construire sa propre maison un jour, de la mettre en location.
texts.en: The Lamp Fall, Port 10 of Beug Manal Sa Bop borrowers’ group is a subgroup  of a network of women processing fish products for sale. The group is composed of five women who have been in business for some years and joined forces in order to benefit from financial support allowing them to strengthen their businesses. Seyni Gadio is the group’s leader. She has been in business for over five years. She launched her fish business with the starting capital of 100,000 West African Francs, and at present has working capital of about 500,000 francs. This loan will allow her to bolster her funds and buy quality fish in order to resell it to hotels. Seyni Gadio is married and has three children. She is taking care of their education paying for supplementary instruction. Her dream is to build her own house one day and to rent it out.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish for resale.

loans.name: Scovia's Group

texts.en:
Scovia's group is comprised of hardworking women. Scovia is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her fruits and vegetables business, which sells vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits, and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and increase the business. Scovia hopes that in the future, she will be able to own a salon. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fruits

loans.name: Nura

texts.en: Nura remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Nura, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Nura  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Nura. With this loan, Nura is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth appreciates the support of the previous loan that helped her to establish a hardware business and now the business is picking up well. Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of 100,000 KES to buy spare parts for both vehicles and motorcycles for sale so that she can earn a higher income than what she is getting. She thanks Yehu and Kiva for the continued support.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for both vehicles and motorcycles

loans.name: Shani

texts.en:
Shani appreciates the previous loan that helped her expand her business.
	
For the past three years, Shani has operated a business selling clothes and shoes, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 50,000 KES, Shani wants to purchase bales of clothes and shoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes to resell.

With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.use: to buy more clothes.

loans.name: Brenda's Group

texts.en:
Brenda's group is comprised of hard working women. Brenda is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past 2 years, Brenda has been working hard to manage her soft drinks business, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Brenda has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more soft drinks, and will help Brenda to generate greater profits and build a rental house. Brenda hopes that in the future she will be able to own more rental houses. 

Brenda is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more soft drinks

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en:
Annet's group is comprised of hardworking women. Annet is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Annet has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food and utensils, and will help Annet to generate greater profits and provide basic needs. Annet hopes that in the future, she will be able to become a tailor. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more food and utensils

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community

loans.name: Thêm

texts.en:
Mrs. Thêm works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. Thêm has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

The main hardship that Thêm faces in her life is not having a hygienic latrine. She is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a toilet and bathroom.

Thêm is 35 years old, and she is married with two children. Thêm supports two dependents with her business in Nong Cong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2014, Thêm joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Thêm has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

In the future, Thêm hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to maintain a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement and brick to build a toilet and bathroom

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Gabina

texts.es:
La socia Gabina  se dedica al negocio de crianza de animales menores como cuyes y gallinas, la socia los hace engordar y crecer y luego los vende en las diferentes ferias y mercados, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 4 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los animales. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar cuyes y gallinas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
This member, Gabina, has a business raising small animals, such as guinea pigs and chickens. She fattens them, lets them grow and then sells them in different markets. She works from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. and has had this business, which is going well, for 4 years.

Gabina dreams of having a venue where she can sell her animals. She is requesting a loan to purchase guinea pigs and chickens.

The member is happy with the loan

loans.use: to purchase guinea pigs and chickens.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La socia Luz MARINA se dedica al negocio de crianza de pollos y tambien se dedica al negocio de venta de pollipapas que es un plato a base de pollos y papas, la socia los pollos los hace engordar y crecer y luego los vende en las diferentes mercados,la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los pollos. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar pollos y alimentos para los pollos.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Luz Marina makes a living raising chickens, and also sells “pollipapas,” a dish made of chicken and french fries. Luz Marina fattens and raises the chickens, and then sells them in different markets. She has several years of experience in this business and is doing very well. Her dream is to have her own place to sell the chickens. Luz Marina is requesting this loan to buy more chickens and chicken feed. 

Luz Marina is happy for the loan and is committed to making her repayments.

loans.use: to buy chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Saratu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Saratu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Saratu.  With this loan, Saratu is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Rose is 16 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past one year, Rose has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans and soda. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential goods for sale, and will help Rose to generate greater profits, add more capital and employ other workers. Rose hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase for more essential goods for sale

loans.name: Veronica De La Concepcion

texts.es:
Veronica de 38 años de edad, casado con tres hijos menores de edad, es originaria de Nagarote, lugar que está ubicado en la zona de occidente del país.   Se caracteriza por ser trabajadora, responsable, con ganas de separación personal. Lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos no pudo cursar una carrera y se vio en la necesidad de trabajar desde muy joven. En la actualidad lucha arduamente para poder salir adelante con su sus pequeños, y llegar a cumplir sus sueños y metas como las tiene cualquier persona, terminar su casa, y formar  a sus hijos en profesionales.
Gracias su esfuerzo y sus ganas de salir adelante tiene por actividad económica un bar y comedor ubicado en su casa de habitación, el cual atiendo a todo tipo de clientes ofreciendo platos caseros variados y refrescos naturales, gaseosos, como: carne en baho, carne asada, pollo frito, pollo empanizado, pollo en caldo, jugos, gaseosas. Ella dedica a su negocio unas doce horas diarias ofreciendo su producto.  el objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y comprar productos comestibles para poder preparar los diferentes platos  de comida. Como: arroz, frijoles, aceite, lechuga, carne, pollo, verduras, condimentos. Veronica agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Veronica, 38 years old, is married with three small children. She is originally from Nagarote, which is located in the Western side of the country. She is known as hardworking, responsible, and eager for self-improvement. Unfortunately due to lack of funds, she was unable to pursue a degree and was left to work at a young age. 
 
Presently, she struggles hard to get her children ahead and to fulfill her dreams and goals, just as anyone else, like finishing her house and having her children become professionals.

Thanks to her efforts and her desire to succeed, she set up  an eating establishment out of her home, from where she caters to all kinds of clients, offering various homemade dishes and refreshments - both natural and soft drinks. Her offerings include baho meat, roasted meat, fried chicken, breaded chicken, chicken broth, juices, and sodas.  She works twelve hours daily at the business. 

The purpose of the credit is to buy groceries for preparing different food dishes, including buying rice, beans, oil, lettuce, meat, poultry, vegetables, and seasonings. 

Veronica appreciates the assistance that Kiva investors provide to people with scarce resources in poor countries like Nicaragua, allowing them to hold dignified jobs.

loans.use: stock her business with ingredients to prepare and sell dishes such as baho meat, roast beef, fried chicken, breaded chicken, chicken broth, juices, and sodas.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a cereals shop business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Josephine dreams of establishing a wholesale cereals shop business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase stock of wheat, maize, beans and rice for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat, maize, beans and rice for sale

loans.name: Yusuf Madakin-Daji

texts.en: Yusuf Madakin-Daji is a Babban Gona farmer from Furana. Yusuf Madakin-Daji expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Yusuf Madakin-Daji to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf Madakin-Daji can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf Madakin-Daji, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Yusuf Madakin-Daji will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland”. With this loan, Yusuf Madakin-Daji will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
A hardworking woman, Flora is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past two years, Flora has been working hard to manage her agriculture farm, which rears a cow. 

To help expand her business, Flora has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to buy more cows. This will help Flora to generate greater profits and later buy a goat to add to the farm. She hopes that in the future she will be able to learn salon work. 

Flora is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more cows

loans.name: Adan Jose

texts.es: El señor Adán, habita en el municipio de Ticuantepe en la comarca llamada Esquipulas, soltero convive con su mama, labora como guarda de seguridad en una empres privada desde hace 4 años, ademas don Adán tiene un pequeño vivero en su casa donde vende Grama por metros, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de materiales de construcción como cemento, arena, bloques, hierro ya que realizara un cuarto para tener si mayor privacidad, agradece la oportunidad que le están brindando con este crédito.
texts.en: Adán lives in the municipality of Ticuantepe in the region called Esquipulas.  He is single and lives with his mom.  He has worked as a security guard in a private business for the past 4 years and, in addition, he has a small nursery in his house where he sells lawn grass by the meter. He asks for this loan to purchase construction materials such as cement, sand, concrete blocks, and iron so that he can make a room to have improved privacy. He is grateful for the opportunity that he is being offered with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Laura Clarisa

texts.es:
Laura, es madre de dos hijos de 6 y 2 años de edad, vive con sus hijos y su padre, es soltera; su fuente de ingresos es la venta de tortillas, tiene su negocio desde hace 2 años, trabaja junto a su hermana de las 4:00 p.m. a 6:30 p.m., en este horario atrae a más clientes por lo que es una ventaja.
Utilizará el capital que requiere para comprar leña, cal, maíz, bolsas y papel, teniendo la materia prima elaborara la venta de tortillas sin problemas, espera administrar bien el capital de trabajo  para evitar riesgos que eviten cumplir con los pagos de su deuda.
Laura anhela continuar dando a sus hijos una educación de calidad y cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia.
texts.en:
Laura is the mother of two children, 6 and 2 years old. She lives with her children and her father; she is single.  Her source of income is the sale of tortillas and she has had her business for the past two years.  She works with her sister from 4:00 pm to 6:30 pm; with this schedule she attracts more customers which is an advantage.  She will use the capital that she needs to purchase firewood, lime, corn, bags, and paper, and having these raw materials will make tortillas to sell without difficulty. She expects to manage the working capital well to avoid risks that would prohibit her from making the payments on her debt. 

Laura desires to continue giving her children a quality education and paying for her family's basic necessities.

loans.use: to purchase firewood, lime, corn, bags and paper, and having these raw materials she will make tortillas to sell without difficulty.

loans.name: Bawa

texts.en: Bawa remembers the depression he felt  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Bawa, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Bawa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Bawa. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Pancha Sussana

texts.es:
La socia Pancha Sussana se dedica al negocio de venta de comida, la socia realiza diferentes platos como pollo al horno, sopas y saltados de carne, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene 8 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un restaurant. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar productos para cocinar como arroz, verduras y pollo.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Pancha Sussana works in her business selling food. She makes different dishes such as baked chicken, soups, and pan-seared meat. She works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm, she already has been in this business for 8 years and it is going very well for her. Her dream is to have a restaurant. She asks for this loan to purchase cooking products such as rice, vegetables, and chicken.

She is happy for the loan and commits to making the payments on her loan.

loans.use: to purchase cooking products such as rice, vegetables, and chicken.

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
La socia Estela se sigue dedicando al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azucar, leche y galletas, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azucar, leche y galletas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Estela continues to work in her grocery store business.  She sells basic products such as rice, sugar, milk, and cookies. She works from 8:00 am to 7:00 pm, and she has had this business for 5 years and it is going very well for her. Her dream is to expand the grocery store business. She asks for this loan to purchase rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

She is happy for the loan and commits to making the payments on her loan.

loans.use: to purchase rice, sugar, milk and cookies.

loans.name: Meyster

texts.es:
Meyster es un joven soltero, emprendedor, con 22 años de edad, habita en San Martin junto a su familia. Desde muy joven ha apoyado a sus padres en la chacra para poder contribuir con los gastos del hogar. Es una persona muy trabajadora y le gusta lo que hace. Está familiarizado con la naturaleza, le encanta los ambientes naturales y a su corta edad tiene mucha experiencia en cuanto a agricultura.
