Sus visiones son cancelar la deuda adquirida y proveer a su hijo de todo lo necesario para tener un mejor ambiente familiar.
texts.en: Ofelia sells fruits and vegetables in the municipal market in her town. She is currently single and she is the mother of six children. She lives alone with one of them; the others already have their own homes. She has 35 years of experience selling produce and she has improved thanks to the use of loans. She has also constructed her house on credit. She will invest the loan that she is applying for in the purchase of radishes, tomatoes, strawberries, papayas, and other varieties of fresh fruits and vegetables to stock her inventory during vacation time. She hopes to increase her sales and increase her profits. Her vision is to repay her debts and provide her son with all that he needs to have a better family environment.

loans.use: to buy radishes, tomatoes, strawberries, papayas, and other varieties of fresh fruits and vegetables to stock her inventory during vacation time.

loans.name: Carlos Eduardo

texts.es:
Carlos es un padre dedicado, vive en Pueblo Nuevo junto a su familia. Tiene un hijo quien es su mayor motivación en la vida para salir adelante. Desde muy joven ha trabajado para poder sacar adelante a su familia porque es una persona muy emprendedora, es por ello que ya tiene 3 años trabajando como Obrero de Campo en una empresa Agroexportadora. El excelente resultado de su trabajo se da por su buen desempeño y porque sus padres lo inculcaron con muchos valores desde pequeño, los mismos valores que inculca hoy a su hijo.
Carlos está agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva por el apoyo que le han brindado porque gracias a ello él podrá remodelar su vivienda como pintarrajear las paredes y cambiar la cerradura de la puerta de su casa para que de esta manera su familia pueda vivir con mayor seguridad, así pues, estará mejorando su calidad de vida y seguirá esforzándose para poder más adelante cumplir uno de sus mayores sueños: "Tener su casa propia".
texts.en:
Carlos is a dedicated father and lives with his family in Pueblo Nuevo. His son is his main motivation for wishing to make progress in life. Ever since he was a young man he has worked to help his family get ahead; he is very enterprising and has already worked as a laborer for the business Agroexportadora for three years. His excellent work is a result of working hard and following the values his parents taught him when he was young, values that today he is passing on to his son.

Carlos is grateful to Kiva donors for the support they bring him. As a result he will be able to make improvements to his house such as plaster the walls and change the lock on the door. Then his family will be able to live in greater security. He will be improving his quality of life and working towards one of his biggest dreams: to have a house of his own.

loans.use: Make improvements to his house

loans.name: Nils Orlando

texts.es:
Nils tiene 31 años de edad, estado civil conviviente tiene 2 hijos a su cargo, cuenta con casa propia en el distrito de Nueva Arica en la provincia de Chiclayo en la región de Lambayeque - Perú, en este distrito se dedica a la agricultura y a la crianza y venta de animales de corral este distrito es una zona rural.

Nils se dedica al comercio de crianza y venta de animales de corral, tiene ya varios años de experiencia; solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por el monto de 2000 nuevos soles, loa cuales invertirá en la compra de animales pequeños para que luego de dos meses los pueda revender y asi obtenga mejores resultados económicos para ayudar a su familia, mejorando la calidad de vida de esta.
texts.en:
Nils is 31 years old. He lives with his companion and has two children in his care. He has his own home in the district of Nueva Arica in the province of Chiclayo in the region of  Lambayeque - Perú. In the district, many work in agriculture and raise and sell livestock. This district is a rural zone. 

Nils has a business raising and selling livestock. He has several years of experience. He is applying for a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for the amount of 2000 nuevos soles, which he will invest in the purchase of small animals so the he can resell them two months later and obtain a higher price to help his family and improve their quality-of-life.

loans.use: to buy nutritious food to fatten his animals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her son's education

loans.name: Clemencue Group

texts.en: Army is the featured borrower of Clemencue group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua because they have always been friends since they left their hometown in the Philippines to come and work in Lebanon with a better income to support their beloved ones back in the Philippines. Army is a 42-year-old divorced mother of three who works as a housekeeper to provide her family with a better living through the acquired income from her current job. Life in the Philippines is very expensive and job opportunities are limited. Army is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees. Army is the lady standing at the far left side of the picture with a pink top. As for the other group members, Merly is the second lady from the right side of the picture, Mayvel is the second lady from the left with an orange top, while Remy is the first from the right.

loans.use: to pay for her children's school tuition fees

loans.name: Maris Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Maris es una persona  muy  emprendedora vive con  su esposo y sus   hijos. Su negocio es la elaboración y venta de tortillas desde  hace más de 10 años. 
Doña Maris el préstamo lo necesita para la compra de maíz, leña y cal. Con el crédito espera que sus ventas aumenten debido a que contara con más capital para obtenerlos los productos que sus clientes le solicitan a diario, así mismo espera que mejore su situación económica en el hogar y que se vea reflejado con esta inversión. 
Doña Maris en unos años sueña con que su negocio  este posicionado como el más grande y  conocido de la zona y poder seguir apoyando a  su familia  e hijos.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio    del 2014
texts.en:
Maris is a very entrepreneurial person. She lives with her husband and her children. Her business has been the production and sale of tortillas for 10 years.

Maris needs the loan to purchase corn, firewood, and lime. With the loan, she hopes that her sales increase owing to that she will count on more capital to obtain them for the products that he customers request from her daily. She also hopes to improve her economic situation in the home and that it is seen reflected with this investment.

Maris dreams that in a few years her business be positioned as the largest and best known in the zone and to be able to continue supporting her family and children.

Choluteca, Honduras – July, 2014

loans.use: to purchase corn, firework, and lime for her business.

loans.name: Maria Marleny

texts.es:
Maria tiene 41 años de edad, su estado civil es conviviente, tiene 1 hijo a su cargo, cuenta con casa propia en el caserío de Chilcal el cual pertenece al distrito de Oyotún en la provincia de Chiclayo en la región de Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú; este caserio se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales de corral los cuales los venden a compradores de Cayalti y lugareños.

Maria se dedica al comercio venta y crianza de animales de corral como patos, gallinas y cuyes. Ella solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa para el mejoramiento del corral de sus animales y compra de estos para obtener mejores ingresos, mayores ganancias y con ello mejorar la calidad de vida de ella y de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria is 41 years old, she lives with her partner and she has one child. She has her own house in the small village of Chilcal which is in the district of Oyotún, in the province of Chicalayo, in the Lambayeque region on the North coast of Peru. This small village is known for raising and selling barnyard animals, which are sold to locals and buyers from Cayalti.

Maria makes a living by raising and selling barnyard animals such as ducks, chickens and guinea pigs. She is asking for a loan from Edpyme Alternativa to improve the animal pen and to buy animals to achieve a higher income and a larger profit, which will improve the quality of life for her and her family.

loans.use: to improve the pen where she keeps her animals.

loans.name: Mirian

texts.es:
La señora Miriam  es una persona responsable, trabajadora y honesta, vive  con su esposo y sus dos hijos en el  sur de Honduras. Su negocio es  la  venta  de ropa  y cosméticos. 
Doña Miriam el préstamo lo necesita para la compra  de  lociones, perfumes, cremas,  talcos,   blusas,  vestidos  y ropa interior etc. Con el préstamo espera que las ventas en su negocio aumenten al tener más producto que ofrecer y atender mejor  a sus clientes. 
Doña Miriam espera cubrir las necesidades  que tiene y mejorar un poco su calidad  de vida y la de su familia. En unos años espera que su negocio siga  creciendo  y se convierta en una tienda más grande y reconocido de la zona y que sus hijos  se conviertan en personas de bien y con mejores oportunidades en la vida. 	



Choluteca, Honduras  –  Julio del   2014
texts.en:
Sra. Miriam is a responsible, hardworking and honest person. She lives with her husband and two children in the south of Honduras. She earns her living selling clothing and cosmetics. Now she needs a loan to buy lotions, perfume, creams, talc, dresses, and underwear. As a result of the loan she expects to increase sales as she will have more products to offer her customers and will be better able to please them.

Miriam hopes to cover the cost of basic necessities and improve a little her standard of living and that of her family. In a few years she hopes to see her business become one of the biggest and best known in the area. She also hopes that her children become good citizens with better life opportunities.

Choluteca, Honduras--July 2014

loans.use: buy lotions, perfume, creams, talc, dresses, and underwear

loans.name: Mwanapili

texts.en: Mwanapili sells fruits and green vegetables in her stall. She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more. Mwanapili is requesting a loan to buy a variety of sacks of fruit and green vegetables for resale and she thanks Yehu and Kiva at large for the support.

loans.use: to buy a variety of sacks of fruit and green vegetables for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy special fabric to make the aprons her customers have ordered

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is a married woman with children, all under her care. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Neema wants to start a vegetable- and fruit-selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit-vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason, she decided to join Yehu to get financial support. With her loan of KES 20,000, she plans to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaws.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaws to sell.

loans.name: Plan

texts.en:
Phan, age 23, is single, and lives with her brother and grandmother in suburb of Phnom Penh City.  
Phan is a garment factory worker. She hopes to build an addition to the front of her house which would be larger and easier for her family members to live in. That’s why she decided to apply for a loan!    
Phan is pictured with her brother.

loans.use: to build an addition to the front of her house.

loans.name: Novie

texts.en:
This is Novie. She has previously accessed and repaid a loan that she used to buy additional grocery items for her variety store. At this time, Novie also owns and operates a utility vehicle which is used to provide transportation service and she earns additional profit from it. She has been successful in this business for years and she finds ways to further improve her income.

Novie would like to take a new loan to buy spare parts and accessories for her vehicle. She is requesting an amount of PHP 20,000 for the maintenance of the van and to buy more stock of other products needed in her business.

In the future, Novie wants to have another transportation vehicle for business purposes for she desires to give her children a good quality education. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from her religion. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study religion, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of her utility vehicle

loans.name: Maximeno

texts.en:
Maximeno is 74 years old and lives in Lupagan Clarin, Philippines. He is married with 3 children. 
Maximeno works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. He has been doing this for 10 years. He has requested a loan to purchase more kilos of fish to sell.
Maximeno has been a member of PMPC for 5 years. In the future, Maximeno hopes to save for an emergency.

loans.use: to purchase more kilos of fish to sell

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
This is Juanita. Her previous loan was a big help for her business, as she was able to purchase products for her direct-selling business. The loan was also useful in the education of her children. Her income from the loan assisted with their everyday expenditures at home. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for a new 45,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan. It will be used to buy additional supplies and merchandise, such as clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from this business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Juanita hopes to prosper and become successful through her business. She also desires for her children to complete their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Aireen

texts.en: Aireen, 32 years old, is married and has two children. Aireen has been farming tomato in the Philippines for 14 years and earns additional income from raising pigs. She is borrowing PHP 29,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. Aireen is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a peanut butter making business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 21000 through NWTF to buy to buy ingredients and materials for her peanut butter making business to sell.

Sara has been in this business for three years. She earns more income from buying and selling ready to wear products.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and materials for her business

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Lolita is 38 years old and has four children who are in school.

She has a farming rice business in the Philippines. Lolita requested an 18,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of fertilizers for her farm.

Lolita has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Lolita would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but does not have piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has owned a food stall business where neighbours and town dwellers shop. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in clientele volume leading to the loss of perishable goods.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flours, and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding her business into a modern café.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flours, and cooking fat

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables, like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business.

Tabitha is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase stocks of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Htan Pin Chaung Village

texts.en:
Located in Central Myanmar’s Yasagyo township, this community currently has 45 village customers, including 9 CBO (Community Based Organization) committee members who help to lead the loan program in the area. The village is suffering to get clean water because of the drought in the dry zone area. Also, many villagers have to cross the stream in order to reach their farms because they cannot afford to build a bridge.

The new loan will mainly help villagers pay the wages of daily laborers who will help the farmers during the busy planting and harvesting seasons. As many young people are migrating to the cities and neighboring countries, such as Thailand, to be traders, there are not enough people for farming. Farmers usually have to pay day laborers a $3 daily wage and contribute as necessary to room and board. In addition to labor fees, farmers must purchase compost and fertilizer to enrich their crops, such as beans and chickpeas.

Pictured above are the committee members from the Hta Pin Chaung Village CBO: U Thaung, U Ko, Daw Myint, Daw Htay, Daw Yin, Daw Yee, Daw Tin, U Myint and U Kyi. Included in the photo (third from the left) is 46-year-old U Thaung, who has six family members. His two sons are now working as construction workers in Korea.

loans.use: to help 45 villagers pay day laborers who will help with planting and harvesting

loans.name: Mbinga Group

texts.en:
Salome, who is in her mid-30s, is single, with two children who are still in school. She has been a food vendor for four years now.  She works from 5am to 3pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Salome's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to start selling food.  She wakes up very early and makes soup (boiled chicken heads, legs, chicken intestines, and meat soup) and serves it with chapati. She also serves chapati with beans, then she also serves cooked food at around midday and then she goes home at 3pm.  

Salome is happy with the loan because, being a single parent, she can manage to take care of her children. They go to fair schools. She has also managed to successfully pay back her prior loans. She used the profit to pay school fees and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to buy backing flour, cooking oil, sugar, beans, wheat flour, and charcoal to cook the food.

Salome will share this loan with her loan group, Mbinga Group, which has nine members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy backing flour, cooking oil, sugar, beans, wheat flour, and charcoal to cook the food.

loans.name: Genoves

texts.es:
Genovés tiene 39 años de edad; su estado civil es conviviente, tiene un hijo a su cargo, cuenta con casa propia la cúal esta ubicada en el distrito de Oyotún en la provincia de Chiclayo en la región de Lambayeque - Perú; en este distrito la población se dedica a la agricultura y a la crianza de animales, dado que este lugar es una zona rural.

Genovés se dedica al comercio, él cria y vende animales de corral como tales como patos, cuyes y otros; solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa el monto es de 1000 nuevos soles el cual invertirá en la compra de animales pequeños y la crianza de ellos para que luego de unos meses revenderlo para obtener mejores resultados y ganancias, lo que le ayudara a mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Genovés is 39 years old. His marital status is cohabitation. He has a son in his care. He has his own house which i located in the district of Oyotón in the province of Chiclayo in the region of Lambayeque - Peru. In this district the population works in agriculture and the raising of animals, given that this is a rural region.
Genovés works in business. He raises and sells corral animals like ducks, cuyes, and others. He is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 1000 nuevos soles which he will invest in the purchase of small animals and the raising of them to some months later resell them to get better results and earning, which will help him improve his quality of life and that of his family.

loans.use: buy more animals

loans.name: Oscar Mauricio

texts.es:
Oscar, opta un nuevo crédito para comprar insecticidas, abono, semilla y herbicidas para eliminar la maleza del terreno y proteger sus cultivos de plagas, espera tener una buena producción, aumentar las ventas y ganancias.
 Oscar está satisfecho con los buenos resultados que ha tenido al invertir el financiamiento anterior en su negocio, tuvo una cosecha abundante y de calidad, su nueva situación económica le permitió tener puntualidad en el pago de sus cuotas, su grupo familiar se mantiene muy saludable y no manifiesta problemas en su negocio.
texts.en: Oscar requests a new loan to buy insecticides, fertilizers, seeds and herbicides to eliminate weeds and protect his plants from blight. He hopes to have good production and to increase sales and earnings. Oscar is satisfied with the good results that he has had after investing his previous loan. He had an abundant an high-quality harvest. His new economic situation allows him to be punctual in his payments. His family is very healthy and he had no problems in his business.

loans.use: buy insecticides, fertilizer, seeds and herbicides to eliminate the weeds and protects his plants from blight

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is a married woman with children. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

For the past 10 years, Nuru has operated an open-air food-stall business; her potential customers are market dwellers and neighbors. Nuru faces a major challenge of seasonality of products in the market.

With the KES 40,000, Nuru wants to purchase sacks of beans, cooking oil, wheat flour and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, cooking oil, wheat flour and rice.

loans.name: Mourine's Group

texts.en:
MOURINE's group is comprised of four hardworking women. MOURINE is 16 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past one year, MOURINE has been working hard to manage a restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand  business, MOURINE has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more food to sell, and will help MOURINE to generate greater profits, add more capital, and increase the income. 

MOURINE hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a clothing business. 

MOURINE is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more food to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her daughter's education.

loans.name: Shakirah

texts.en:
Shakirah is 23 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past three years, Shakirah has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand  business, Shakirah has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale, and will help Shakirah to generate greater profits and complete her parents' house. Shakirah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Shakirah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Pilika Pilika Group

texts.en:
Suzana, who is in her early 30s, is married with two children who are still at school.  She has been having several projects, bring up broilers from chicks to big chickens for selling, and selling shoes and charcoal.  She has been in her business for four years now.  She works from 07 am to 08 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.  

This will be Suzana's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to start selling shoes, chicken and bought more sacks of charcoal. She is doing fine with the loan.  She used the profit to take part in paying school fees and covered household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy the fast moving type of shoes and up-to-date fashion clothes.  She dreams of building her own house.

Suzana will share this loan with her loan group, "PILIKA PILIKA", which has three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy the fast moving type of shoes and up to date fashion clothes.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence appreciates the previous loan that helpedher expand her business.

For the past 10 years, she has operated an open air food stall business; her potential customers are market dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of seasonality of products in the market.

With the Kshs 80,000, she wants to purchase sacks of beans, cooking fat oil, wheat flour, and rice. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to buy food ingredients and sacks of potatoes.

loans.name: Marta Mirian

texts.es:
La señora Marta  es una persona  muy  emprendedora vive con  su esposo y sus   hijos. Su negocio es el servicio de molino desde  hace más de 10 años. 
Doña Marta el préstamo lo necesita para la compra de bandas, discos, grasa, lima, etc. Con el crédito  espera  el aumento de sus ventas debido a que contara con más capital fresco y producto que ofrecer a los clientes que la visitan y así cubrir sus necesidades.
Doña Marta espera que mejore su situación económica en el hogar y que se vea reflejado con esta inversión. En unos años sueña con que su negocio  este posicionado como el más grande y  conocido de la zona y poder seguir apoyando a  su familia  a que se convierta en personas de bien  para la sociedad y con mejores oportunidades.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio    del 2014
texts.en:
Marta is an enterprising person who lives with her husband and children. Her business has been a grinding mill for more than 10 years. She needs a loan for the purchase of bands, discs, oil, and abrasive files, etc. With the loan, she hopes to increase her sales so she will have more capital and products to offer to the clients who visit her so she can fulfill their needs. 

Marta hopes to improve the economic situation in her home and this is reflected in her investment. She dreams that her business will be bigger and more well-known in the region and that she will be able to continue supporting her family as the become good people in the community and that they have better opportunities. 

Choluteca, Honduras – July  2014

loans.use: to buy bands, discs, oil, and abrasive files, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en:
Kavumbi appreciates the previous loan that helped her expand her business.

Kavumbi operates a charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her villages. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding to increase her monthly income.

With the loan of Kes 20,000, she wants to purchase  sacks of charcoal for resale and pay for transport. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit lives with her husband and 21-year-old son. Both her husband and Anahit are working at a local company that engages in the development of a large vineyard. Besides working there, Anahit and her husband also run their own farm. It includes pigs, chickens and turkeys as well as arable land where haricot beans, tomatoes, watermelons and different fruit trees are cultivated. 

The requested loan of USD 3,000 is very important for Anahit and her farm. She plans to use the loan at purchasing fertilizer, chemicals for cultivation of the land, and feed for the chickens. This is very important to continue developing her farm and make it more profitable.

 Anahit has previously taken a loan from a local financial institution, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back because the family faced difficulties. However, thanks to their recent hard work, Anahit is able to run her agricultural business in a way that ensures that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. The lenders will provide great support to Anahit and her family by giving them an opportunity to receive the loan and to maintain their agricultural business.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer, chemicals for cultivation of the land, and feed for the chickens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her son's education

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is 19 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, Zainabu has been working hard to manage her charcoal business. 

To help expand her business, Zainabu has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale, and will help Zainabu to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her brother. Zainabu hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a poultry business. 

Zainabu is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 16 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Irene has been working hard to manage her clothes business.

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 200,000  Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes for sale, and will help Irene to generate greater profits and add more capital to her business. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes for sale

loans.name: Cross Fire Group

texts.en:
Edna is the featured borrower of Cross Fire Group. She joined with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, because they have always been friends, since they left their hometown in the Philippines to come and work in Lebanon for a better income to support their beloved ones back in the Philippines. 

Edna is a 36-year-old married mother of two who works as a housekeeper to provide her family with a better living through the acquired income from her current job. Life in the Philippines is very expensive, and job opportunities are limited. 

Edna is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees. 

Edna is the lady standing at the far right side of the picture with white top. As for the other group members, Simeona is the lady at the center of the picture, while Rosemarie is the first from the left.

loans.use: To pay for her children's increasing school tuition fees

loans.name: Muhiga Group

texts.en:
MUHIGA, who is in his early 30s, is single.  He has been selling new shoes for sometime.  He works from 02 am to 08 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be MUHIGA's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loan to increase the shoe stock and has successfully paid back his loan.  He is happy with the loan.  He used the profit to take care of himself and the household expenses.  

He will use this loan to buy new and up-to-date shoes to meet his customers' demand and quality.  He dreams of investing more in his shoe business.

MUHIGA will share this loan with loan group, "MUHIGA", which has six members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new and up-to-date shoes to meet his customers' demands and quality.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set  so that he may provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Vesile

texts.en:
Vesile is 31 years old. She is engaged, and is living with her parents in Ahmadbayli village of Fuzuli city, but she is an IDP, an Internaly Displaced Person, from Fuzuli city. 

Vesile has been in a sales business at her little store. Her parents help to Vesile to open this store; she sells parfumery products. 

Today she wants to increase the size of the store, and open part for daily food products. For this reason, she needs a loan in the amount of 2,000 Azerbaijan new manat (AZN). 

Vesile says, “Thanks dear Kiva lenders for support. I’m greatly thankful to you.” 

In the future she wants to get married and develop her business.

loans.use: to increase the size of her shop to sell food products

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Getrude is 18 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past four years, Getrude has been working hard to manage  her charcoal business. 

To help expand her business, Getrude has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more sacks of charcoal for sale, and will help Getrude to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her brothers. Getrude hopes that in the future she will be able to construct her own house. 

Getrude is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Domingo Guzman

texts.es:
Domingo tiene 54 años de edad estado civil conviviente sin hijos a su cargo vive con su conyuge en el caserío de culpón este caserío pertenece al distrito de Nueva Arica en la provincia de Chiclayo en la región de Lambayeque costa norte de Perú, la cual es una zona rural en donde se dedican a la agicultura; crianza y venta de animales

Domingo se dedica al comercio pues compra, crianza y vende animales de corral tales como patos, pollos y cuyes; solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa el monto es de 3000 nuevos soles lo cual invertirá en el mejoramiento del corral en donde criá a sus animales para criarlos en un ambiente más adecuado; lo q le permitirá incrementar sus ingresos, sus ganancias y por ende mejorará su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Domingo is 54 years old and lives with his children, who are in his care, and with his partner, in the little village of Culpón, which belongs to the Nueva Arica district, in the Chiclayo province, in the region of Lambayeque on the northern coast of Peru. This is a rural area where people work in agriculture, raising and selling animals.


Domingo works in trade, buying, raising, and selling small farm animals like ducks, chickens, and guinea pigs. He is requesting this loan with Edpyme Alternativa, which amounts to 300 PEN. He will invest it in the improvement of the pen where he raises his animals, so that he can raise them in a more suitable environment. This will allow him to increase his income, the money he makes, and in the end he will be able to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to improve the infrastructure of his animal housing

loans.name: Jose Reyneri

texts.es:
José, se dispone a sembrar y requiere de más capital para comprar insumos agrícolas con los que  prepara la tierra en la que realizara la siembra de granos básicos y evitara el problema de plagas.
La inversión del capital que se le otorgó anteriormente le ayudo a mejorar su negocio y a tener una mejor situación económica, su familia se ha visto beneficiada por hoy cuenta con mejor alimentación, vestuario y salud.
texts.en: José is ready to sow his crops and needs more capital to buy farming supplies to prepare his land and sow basic grains and avoid plagues. The investment of capital that he made previously helped him to improve his business and his financial circumstances. His family has benefitted in nutrition, clothing, and health.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies with which to prepare his land in order to sow basic grains.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida is a 37-year-old married woman. She has four children. The income generated by her husband is insufficient to cover all their household expenses, so she initiated her business of milk sales. She has been doing it for many years and has become famous for providing good quality milk in her locality. 

With the support of Kashf Foundation, she has gradually improved her business; currently she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to purchase another buffalo. This will help her to increase her sales which will ultimately help in generating more income for her. She is in her 5th loan cycle with a good credit history.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo.

loans.name: Robi

texts.en:
Robi is a 38-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband, who is also shown in the photo.  Her husband also assists her by purchasing a stock of goods from the market, as he has maintained many contacts in the years. They have been running this business for many years to bear their household expenditures. They have five children, and are motivated to provide their family with good quality food, clothing and health. 

She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of PKR 50,000 to buy packs of salts, biscuits, oil, grains and beverages to meet the increasing demand in their store. 

She is expecting boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits, oil, grains and beverages.

loans.name: Irshad

texts.en:
Irshad is a 51-year-old married women. She has been doing a business of selling fruits & vegetables for the past 10 years. She is a very enthusiastic lady, and manages to earn a reasonable amount of money to support her family. She is responsible for providing her children with the basic necessities of life through her business. 

For the improvement for her business, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes and mangos. 

She is in her fourth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes and mangos.

loans.name: Qaisra

texts.en:
Qaisra is a 36-year-old married woman. She deals in a business selling cloth to contribute to the family income. She buys varieties of cloth in different colors and designs from the market at wholesale rates and then sells them to the people of her community. She has a varied customer base and is able to earn enough through her business. 

Qaisra is requesting a 45,000 PKR loan from the Kashf Foundation to buy a wide variety of sorts of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her earnings with her loan and she plans to spend part of her profits on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of types of cloth in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Maqsoda

texts.en:
Maqsoda is 52-year-old married woman.  She has been doing business selling milk with her husband for many years.  She has three buffaloes; she sells milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter and cheese that she makes from the milk.  She looks after the buffaloes and performs the task of collecting their milk on a daily basis. 

Maqsoda has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation and has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers. She expects a boost in her sales and profits after she has the other buffalo.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar-charging device so that she may provide vital farming information to her community.

loans.name: Moureen

texts.en:
Moureen is 20 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, Moureen has been working hard to manage  her little shop which sells movies. 

To help expand her  business, Moureen has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more movies for sale, and will help Moureen to generate greater profits and take good care of herself. Moureen hopes that in the future she will be able to start up another business. 

Moureen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more movies for sale

loans.name: Irene's Group

texts.en:
Irene's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Irene is 23 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Irene has been working hard to manage her hardware shop, where she sells hardware items. 

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items like iron sheets and cement to sell, and will help Irene to generate greater profits and add working capital to the business. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to improve her economic development. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more items like iron sheets and cement to sell

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 16 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Salama has been working hard to manage her clothes business. 

To help expand her business, Salama has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes for sale, and will help Salama to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Salama hopes that in the future she will be able to start up a new business. 

Salama is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes for sale

loans.name: Robert

texts.es:
Robert tiene 26 años de edad, estado civil conviviente, sin hijos a su cargo cuenta con casa propia la cual esta ubicada en el caserío de Tingues en el distrito de Nanchoc, en la provincia de San Miguel en la región de Cajamarca - Perú; en este lugar se dedican a la agricultura y la crianza de animales este caserio es una zona rural.

Robert se dedica al comercio de animales de corral con años de experiencia en el negocio solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por el monto es de 1000 nuevos soles los cuales invertirá en el mejoramiento del corral de sus animales para obtener mejores resultados en su economía para apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Robert is 26 years old. He is married and has no children.  He lives in a house that he owns, located in the small Tingues village in the district of Nanchoc, in the province of San Miguel, in the Cajamarca region of Perú. This is a rural village in which most people make a living farming or raising animals.

Robert sells animals that he raises in corrals. He has several years of experience in this trade. Robert is requesting this loan of 1000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa to invest to improve the corral that houses his animals. This will help him to obtain better results from his business so that he can support his family.

loans.use: to improve the infrastructure of the corrals where his animals are kept.

loans.name: Irene's Group

texts.en:
Irene's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Irene is 22 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past three years, Irene has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans and sodas. 

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential goods for resale, and will help Irene to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a wholesale shop. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more essential goods for resale

loans.name: Shushanik

texts.en:
Shushanik lives in Nairi village of Armavir region. Her big family consists of five people: her husband, her three children and her father-in-law. Shushanik's elder son is an army officer and other family members are engaged in agriculture. They keep cows, hens and sheep as well as cultivating tomatoes, peppers and some grass. 

The requested loan of USD 3000 is very important for Shushanik to purchase materials for renovation of their barn which is very old and damaged. The lenders will provide great support to Shushanik and her family by giving them an opportunity to receive the loan and to maintain their agricultural business.

loans.use: to pay for materials for renovation of their barn

loans.name: Mujeres Triunfadoras Group

texts.es: Josefina forma parte del grupo “Mujeres Triunfadoras” constituida por 08 personas emprendedoras y responsables. Josefina de 48 años es separada con 02 hijos dependientes. Hace 02 años que Josefina se dedica a la venta de papa en un puesto de mercado. De tal manera le ha permitido darles una mejor educación a sus hijos. Así mismo como actividad secundaria alquila cuartos. Con el fin de seguir mejorando su negocio solicitó el crédito para la compra de papas yungai, amarilla y huayro.  El grupo “Mujeres Triunfadoras” agradecen a las personas que hicieron posible éste crédito, pues le  permite su progreso. Josefina es la segunda del lado izquierdo y  polo rosado.
texts.en:
Josefina is part of the group "Mujeres Triunfadoras" which consists of eight responsible and enterprising members. Josefina is 48 years old, separated and living with two dependent children. It has been two years since Josefina began selling potatoes at a market stall. In this way, she has b given her children a better education. Also, as a secondary activity, she rents rooms. 

With the goal of continuing to improve her business, she is requesting this loan to buy yungai potatoes, both white and brown. The group "Mujeres Triunfadoras" is grateful toward the people who have made this loan possible since is allow them to progress. Josefina is the second on the left side and is wearing a pink shirt.

loans.use: to buy yungai potatoes, yellow and brown.

loans.name: Lersin Otmir

texts.es:
Lersyn tiene 20 años de edad, su estado civil es soltero, sin hijos a su cargo vive en casa alquilada la cual esta ubicada en el distrito de Oyotun en la provincia de Chilayo en la región de Lambayeque - Perú, este distrito se dedica a la agricultura y al comercio de animales dicho lugar es una zona rural.

Lersyn se dedica a la venta de productos farmacéuticos hace 6 meses, solicita préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa el monto es de 1500 nuevos soles los cuales invertirá en la compra de más medicamentos para tener un stock surtido y cubrir la demanda de estos; con lo que obtendrá mejores resultados económicos y asi mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Lersyn is 20 years old. He is single and has no children. He lives in a house he rents that is located in the Oyotun district, in the Chilayo province, in the region of Lambayeque in Perú. This is a rural zone, in which, most people make a living farming and selling animals.  

Lersyn has been working, selling pharmaceutical products for the last six months. Now he is requesting this loan of 1500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa to invest in the purchase of more medications to stock his pharmacy. This way he will be able to cover the demand of his customers and obtain more income to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to invest in his business, buying other medications to stock his pharmacy.

loans.name: Henry Cornelio

texts.es:
Henry es un joven padre de familia, tiene 19 años de edad, vive en Ica en la casa de sus suegros junto a su familia.
Tiene un hijo recién nacido, se siente muy contento por este regalo maravilloso que le han podido dar y siempre se esfuerza para poder ofrecerle todas las comodidades a su pequeño. Desde hace más de 1 año se dedica a brindar servicio de taxi en un carro que maneja, le va muy bien porque es una persona honrada, trabajadora y siempre se preocupa en el bienestar de sus clientes y respeta las leyes de tránsito.
Henry está agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado él podrá comprar una cocina para  su vivienda ya que la cocina que tiene está un poco deteriorada y es peligroso. Gracias a esto mejorará su calidad de vida y así seguirá esforzándose para más adelante poder cumplir su más grande sueño: "Tener su casa propia".
texts.en:
Henry is the young father of a his newborn son. Henry is 19 years old and lives in Ica in the home of his in-laws together with their family. He is very happy for this marvelous gift that they have given him and he works hard to be able to offer all the comforts he can to his son. For over a year, Henry has worked as a taxi driver. It has gone very well for him so far because he is an honorable and hardworking man who always worries about the well-being of his customers and respects traffic laws. 

Henry is grateful to Kiva lenders for the support offered to him so that he will be able to buy a kitchen for his home. The kitchen they currently use is very deteriorated and dangerous. Thanks to this loan, Henry will be able to improve his quality of life. He will continue to work hard towards accomplishing his dream of "having his own house."

loans.use: to buy a kitchen for his home.

loans.name: Kithi

texts.en:
Kithi is a married mother of one child, who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.
	

For the past three years, Kithi has operated a clothes and shoes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000, Kithi wants to purchase bales of clothes and shoes to sell. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her son's education

loans.name: Lorena Elizabeth

texts.es:
Lorena, se decidió  por un nuevo préstamo por ser una herramienta útil para seguir generando ingresos económicos, necesita comprar insumos agrícolas y concentrados para cerdos para tener más oportunidades de ampliar su negocio, seguira criando cerdos y cultivando granos básicos.
Lorena cuenta que con el financiamiento anterior incremento la productividad de la granja, los ingresos son mayores y ha cumplido con sus compromisos, ofrece a sus hijos todo lo necesario para que se puedan preparar académicamente y además ha mejorado el estilo de vida familiar.
texts.en:
Lorena decided to take out another loan because it is a useful tool to continue generating income. She needs to buy farming supplies and pellets for pigs so that she will have more opportunities to expand her business. She continues raising pigs and cultivating grains. 

With her previous loan, Lorena increased her farm's productivity as well as her earnings. She made all of her repayments and was able to provide her children with everything they needed to prepare for the academic year. Her family's lifestyle has improved.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies and pellets for pigs so that she will have more opportunities to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and run two Fresh Life Toilets

loans.name: Veronika

texts.en:
Veronika is a hardworking agronomist from the Qarakert village in the Armavir region. She lives with her husband and two sons, who are 18 and 21 years old. The family earns a living through cultivating grass, raising livestock, and growing apricots and plums. Veronika's husband is a migrant worker and her sons help her a lot to sell their agricultural products at the local market. 

Veronika is requesting a 1,600 USD loan to buy some forage for her livestock and some pesticide for her land. She will use her loan to continue her business. Veronika and her family rely on the good will of lenders and are very thankful to them for their support.

loans.use: to buy livestock forage and pesticide

loans.name: Jose Idalio

texts.es: Don Jose Idalio, se dedica al cultivo de granos basicos (maiz y frijol) desde hace 24 años. su grupo familiar lo componen su esposa y sus 3 hijos menores de edad. En la fotografia se observa junto a su cultivo, que ya tiene cierto nivel de crecimiento, pero necesita insumos agricolas para que logre desarrollarse y que el pueda obtener el resultado esperado (cosecha) para cubrir las necesidades basicas de su grupo familiar y continuar con su actividad. pide apoyo financiera para la compra de esos insumos.
texts.en: Jose Idalio has worked growing basic grains (corn and beans) for 24 years.  His family consists of his wife and their three young children.  In the picture, he can be see with his crops, which are already at a certain growth level, but need agricultural supplies so that they can develop, and he can have the desired yield to cover the basic needs of his family and continue working.  He is asking for financial help to purchase these supplies.

loans.use: purchase agricultural supplies to cultivate 1 hectare of corn.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and run one Fresh Life toilet

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
Los guatemaltecos son reconocidos por labrar la tierra desde décadas anteriores desde el comienzo de los mayas ellos tuvieron el privilegio de labrar la tierra y lo realizaron con mucho orgullo, tal como Ramón de 24 años de edad soltero con una gran visión hacia el futuro el realiza esta labor porque la heredo de su padre que realiza la misma labor en cultivar los campos fértiles de Guatemala.
	
El está con la visión de poder realizar este crédito para poder alcanzar logros más importantes en la vida, el emprendió el trabajo de la agricultura porque genera buena ganancia para el futuro de su familia.

La utilización que el realizara al nuevo crédito que el está realizando es para la compra de insumos agrícolas para la siembra de papas en su terreno que tiene disponible par sembrar y cosechar. Con el primer préstamo que el realizo gracias a ello el pudo cultivar una cuerda de papas mas para tener mejores ingresos económicos para su familia.

Uno de los sueños de Ramón es la siembra de mas papas porque el no se conforma con lo poco que el tiene el quiere obtener más terrenos para siembra de papas que el realiza.
texts.en:
Guatemalans are known for having worked the earth for many decades. Since the beginning of the Mayan civilization, they have had the privilege of working the ground, and they have done so with a lot of pride.  Ramón is 24 years old, is single, and has a great vision for the future.  He works as a farmer because he inherited the trade from his father who also works cultivating the fertile fields of Guatemala.  

His plan is to obtain this loan so that he can reach greater heights in life.  He started working as a farmer because it generates a good income for his family's future.  He will use the new loan to purchase agricultural supplies to plant potatoes on his land, which is ready to plant and harvest.  With the first loan that he received, he was able to grow potatoes and generate greater earnings for his family.  

One of Ramon's dreams is to grow more potatoes because he is not satisfied with the little amount that he has now and he wants to acquire more land to grow his potatoes.

loans.use: purchase agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
Asma is a 33-year-old vigorous lady who has been stitching clothes for many years. She sews for the people of her community and uses her income to support her entire family. However, due to her lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. Asma is in her third loan cycle and she has a good credit history. 

Asma is requesting a 40,000 PKR loan from the Kashf Foundation to buy more spools of threads in different colors along with the packs of laces, zippers, and buttons. She will use her loan to increase her revenue and generate healthier source of income.

loans.use: to buy spools of thread in different colors and packs of laces, zippers, and buttons

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji is a 60-year-old farmer from Tashar Ango.  As a Babban Gona member, Alhaji is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alhaji can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Alhaji is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Rabi.U,Inna, and Balaraba. My overall goal is to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Hellen's Group

texts.en:
Hellen's Group is comprised of four hard-working women. Hellen is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro, in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past two years, Hellen has been working hard to manage her clothes business, in which she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Hellen has requested a loan of UGX 700,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes to sell and will help Hellen to generate greater profits and help her young sisters get school fees. Hellen hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build her own house. 

Hellen is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: replace his audio equipment.

loans.name: Surajo Umar

texts.en: Surajo Umar is a maize farmer from Auchan.  As a Babban Gona member, Surajo Umar is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Surajo Umar can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Surajo Umar is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Surajo Umar is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Sadiq,  and Simon. Surajo Umar’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are well educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur is a 35-year-old man. He has been married for 8 years and has a son who is going to first class in this year. His wife is a housewife and helps Zaur on his business. The family members are IDPs (internally displaced persons) from Fuzuli City and now live in the Fuzuli region. Zaur has been in the animal breeding business. He buys little calves, raises them and then sells them in a bazaar to earn money. Today he wants to vaccinate his animals and therefore Zaur has requested for a loan in amount of 1,100 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). Zaur is thankful to the Kiva organization and lenders for this help. In the future Zaur wants to start to produce dairy products and sell them.

loans.use: to pay for vaccinations his animals.

loans.name: Al Rawad Group

texts.en:
Lama is the featured borrower of Al Rawad Group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, because they have always been neighbors and friends.

They all work hard to support their beloved families with an additional income, so their acquired loan is a very important step forward towards making their dreams come true.

Lama is a 24-year-old, married mother of one child, who has been working in the beauty business for 11 years. She was very young when she started working, but she had to support her family in covering their needs. This long experience provided her with special talents and customers' trust and support.

Today, Lama is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, to expand her working sector by increasing her business merchandise with special summer beauty products and cosmetics.

Lama is the second woman from the right, with a pink top. As for the other group members, Rasha is the first on the left, with long, blond hair, Faten is the first from the right, and Rajaa is the second from the left, in green.

loans.use: to expand her working sector by increasing her business merchandise with special summer beauty products and cosmetics.

loans.name: Alasan

texts.en: Alasan is a maize farmer from Ang/Jaki.  As a Babban Gona member, Alasan is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alasan can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Alasan is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Alasan is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Ibrahim,  and  Suleiman. Alasan’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are well educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Samali

texts.en:
Samali is 16 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past year, Samali has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans, and soda. 

To help expand her business, Samali has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential goods for resale, and will help Samali to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself and her sister. Samali hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Samali is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more essential goods for resale

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu is a 19 year old maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Adamu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Adamu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Adamu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Adamu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en:
Perveen is 52 years old and the mother of nine children. The man shown in the picture is her husband, who is a tailor by profession. He knows well the techniques of stitching and earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help him continue operation of his business, Perveen has requested a loan of Rs.50000/- to Kashf Foundation to enable him to purchase a new sewing machine along with spools of threads in various colors.  She is positive that her husband's income will increase by completing customers' orders on time.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine along with spools of threads in various colors.

loans.name: Yahaya Dauda

texts.en: Yahaya Dauda is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Yahaya Dauda joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Natha,Firdausi, and Christian. Yahaya Dauda is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Yahaya Dauda will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Yahaya Dauda can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Yahaya Dauda is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu is a 35-year-old farmer from Kargo.  As a Babban Gona member, Saratu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Saratu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Saratu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, she will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season. Saratu is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children; Dantala,  and  Dorcas,. Saratu’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, she expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Habiban

texts.en:
Habiban, age 44, is a married woman who has a business selling goats. At present, she has five goats and her business is good enough to allow her to lead a decent life. Habiban has five children and is very motivated to provide them with a beautiful life with good education, food, and clothing. It is her seventh year with Kashf Foundation and she has happily improved her business with support from the foundation. 

Habiban is requesting a 45,000 PKR loan to purchase more baby goats. She is hopeful to increase her income and she dreams of expanding her business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase baby goats

loans.name: Ahsan

texts.en:
Ahsan is 40 years old and is married with a child. His child is in the seventh class of school and his wife is a housewife. Ahsan and his family are internally displaced persons (IDPs) from their motherland Fuzuli city. Now they are living in Ahmadbayli village in the Fuzuli region. Ahsan is a taxi driver.

Ahsan is requesting a 700 AZN loan from the Komak Credit Union to repair his car’s motor. He says thanks for the support of the Kiva organization.

loans.use: to repair his car's motor

loans.name: Tasleem

texts.en:
Tasleem is a hardworking woman who works selling animals. She buys baby goats and calves at low prices, brings them up, and then sells them in the market a higher price. Tasleem makes enough money through her business to contribute to her family’s income. She also sells milk to generate extra income. Tasleem is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. She is in her eighth loan cycle and has a good credit history.

Tasleem is requesting a 45,000 PKR loan from the Kashf Foundation to purchase more animals. She will use her loan to expand and improve her business to provide for her household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase animals

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy is a married woman and has 5 children. She describes herself as focused. She operates a farm where she grows tea. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are locals. 

She will use the 80,000 KES loan to buy more stock of tea leaves to sell. Her business goal is to excel within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be a better business woman. She will use the anticipated profits to pay loans and school fees.

loans.use: buy more stock of tea leaves to sell.

loans.name: Matanat

texts.en:
Matanat is 48 years old. She is living in Boyuk Bahmanli village of Fuzuli region with her lovely family: her husband, son, and daughter. Both of her children are going to school. The family members are IDP’s (Internally Displaced Persons) from the city of Fuzuli. 

Matanat and her husband try to develop their family business. They have been in the breeding business. Today, Matanat needs a loan of 2,300 AZN to buy three cows. She says great thanks for the support to the Kiva organization.

loans.use: to buy three cows for her animal breeding business.

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia is a 60-year-old woman. A year ago she started  selling cloth which she purchases from the main city and then sells to the people of her vicinity. She has become famous for selling good quality cloth. 

Razia has requested a loan of PKR 40,000 from Kashf Foundation to buy a stock of various cloths consistent with the choices and tastes of her customers. In this way, she will be able to earn more income through more sales. This will be her seventh loan, and she has shown a good repayment history.

loans.use: to buy a stock of different cloth.

loans.name: Munawer

texts.en:
Munawer is a married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. She has 3 years of experience in this field.  Her husband also assists her by purchasing goods from the market, as he has maintained many contacts over the years. She is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing, and health. 

She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages for her general store.

loans.name: Charistchana

texts.en:
Charistchana is a married woman with 5 children.  Her husband is a laborer who earns money for the family.  It was very tough to manage her house hold needs with only her husband's small income. She decided to help her husband and earn money herself. 

She started her business to buy a variety of fabrics from wholesalers and sell in her area. She now contributes a very important part to her family's income. In order to purchase a variety of fabric in different colors, she has applied for 40,000 PKR. 

She is in her 7th loan cycle with a good credit history.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of fabrics in different colors .

loans.name: Al Sultan 2 50328 Group

texts.en:
Sarah is the featured borrower of Al Sultan 2 50328  group. She joined the group of neighbors and friends to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua. They  work hard to support their beloved families with an additional income.  This loan is a very important step towards realizing their dreams. 

Sarah is a 23-year-old single woman who is an accountant in a well known company. She works hard to cover her education expenses, but her salary isn't good enough to cover unexpected increases.

She requests a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, to pay tuition fees to attend university.  She hopes to continue to pay the fees and related costs. 

Sarah is shown in the center, Fadia is the first from the right, and Wafica is the first from the left.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees to attend university.

loans.name: Oristilia

texts.es:
La señora Orestilia es una persona  muy  emprendedora vive con  su esposo y sus   hijos. Su negocio es venta de frutas desde  hace más de 4 años. 
Doña Orestilia el préstamo lo necesita para la compra de  café,  azúcar, refrescos,  maíz, manteca,  carne, arroz, pan, leche, huevos, queso, harina, etc. espera que esta inversión le permita que sus ventas aumenten gracias a que contara con más capital fresco que ofrecer a los clientes que la visitan  y así cubrir sus necesidades, así mismo espera que mejore su situación económica en el hogar y que se vea reflejado con esta inversión. 
Doña Orestilia en unos años  sueña con que su negocio  este posicionado como el más grande y  conocido de la zona y poder seguir apoyando a  su familia  a que se convierta en personas de bien  para la sociedad y con mejores oportunidades.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio    del 2014
texts.en:
Orestilia is a very enterprising woman.  She lives with her husband and their children.  She has a business selling fruit, which she has run for over four years.  Orestilia is in need of this loan to purchase coffee, sugar, beverages, corn, lard, meat, rice, bread, milk, eggs, chess, flour and other items.  She hopes that the investment will allow for her sales to increase since she will have more fresh products to offer to her customers.  With this, she will be able to cover her household expenses and improve her financial situation at home.

Orestilia hopes that in the coming years, her business will become the largest and most well-known business in the region, and that it will allow her to continue to support her family so that they can do good in the community and have better opportunities.

Choluteca, Honduras- July, 2014
